title: Online onsite admission test Radio Navigation v23.3

questions.query: Regarding A3 modulation, the number (3) means the carrier wave is...

options.text: interrupted three times per minute in order to add Morse-code information.

questions.query: Frequency modulation is used in the...

options.text: ILS system for the modulation of the 90 and 150 Hz navigation signals.
CVOR system for the transmission of the reference signal.
options.comment: The GPS receiver clock is not synchronised with the satellite clock. Differences are corrected in the receiver by measuring to a fourth satellite.

options.text: GPS system to synchronise the satellite clock  and the receiver clock.

questions.query: The lower and upper limit of the VHF band are respectively...

Information can be transmitted by radio waves by...

  1. temporary interruption of the transmission;
  2. modulating the amplitude of the carrier wave;
  3. modulating the frequency of the carrier wave.
If a signal of 1 MHz is amplitude modulated on a carrier wave of 100 MHz, then the bandwidth (B) is...
The transmission of a 1020 Hz Morse ident is a form of...

options.text: Pulse Duration Modulation (PDM) also known as Pulse Width Modulation (PWM).

questions.query:
Which part of the electromagnetic radiofrequency spectrum is assigned to aviation?

 

Note: Choose the most complete alternative.

options.comment:
Correct.

Although the VLF band from 3-30 kHz and the EHF band from 30-300 GHz has no current applications.

questions.query: The photograph below shows a...

Given: A vertical transmitting antenna.

 

When the receiving antenna is placed horizontally, there will be in theory...

options.text: an AC voltage caused by both the electric field and the magnetic field.
an AC voltage caused by the electric field only.
an AC voltage caused by the magnetic field only.

options.comment:
Correct.

The electric field nor the magnetic field can induce a voltage when the two antennas are placed perpendicular to each other.

questions.query: The polarisation of a vertical antenna is...

options.comment:
Polarisation is always related to the direction of the E-field.

The E-field is aligned with (parallel to) the antenna length.

questions.query: The polarisation of a horizontal antenna is...
A loop antenna can be made by two dipoles, physically mounted...

options.comment:
Correct.

A loop antenna is a series connection of two dipoles that are physically parallel to each other.

questions.query: Ground-based MLS antennas are...
The area between the two "nulls" of an antenna diagram is called...
Another name for ground waves is...
VHF radio waves are...
An aeroplane at an altitude of 3000 ft, has a radio horizon of approximately...
Radio waves without skywaves exist...

options.text: at frequencies with wavelengths less than 10 meters.

questions.query:
Bonus question!

Als je deze goed hebt, mag je een andere fout beantwoorde vraag terugtrekken!

 

A radio transmitter has a frequency of 2 MHz and the transmitting power for a range of 1000 wavelengths.

If during a transmission in the night the F-layer (no E and D layers) is at an altitude of 300 km, and the critical angle of incidence is 21º, the distance of the skip zone is approximately...

options.comment:
Correct.

tan 21 = half skip distance / 300 -> skip distance is 230 km.

At 2 MHz, 1 wave length = 3x108 / 2x106 = 150 m -> 1000 wave lengths is 150 km.

Skip zone is 230 - 150 = 80 km.

questions.query: Super refraction is due to a(n)...

options.text: abnormally high ionisation density caused by more intense sun-spot activity.
high static charge of cumulonimbi caused by thunderstorms.
very high seawater surface temperature, for example in tropical coastal seas.
inversion (increasing temperature with altitude) and/or a sharp decrease of the relative humidity with altitude.

questions.query: When comparing with linear (vertical or horizontal) polarised antennas, circular polarised antennas...

options.text: are less sensitive to the attitude of the aircraft.

questions.query: QDM is the ...

options.text: magnetic bearing of an aircraft taken by a VDF station.
true bearing of an aircraft taken by a VDF station.
true heading to the station depending on the wind.
magnetic heading to the station in still air.

questions.query: VDF responds to the...
How does the needle of the VDF indicator responds, when the pilot only presses the push-to-talk (PTT) button?

options.text: Nothing happens until the pilot starts to talk in the microphone.
The indicator needle shows an ambiguous bearing until the pilot starts to talk in the microphone.
The indicator needle goes to the parking position.
The indicator needle shows the bearing unambiguously.

questions.query: The indicator of the ground VDF equipment responds to the...

options.text: voice modulated signal transmitted by the aircraft.

questions.query:
Air traffic control (ATC) gives the pilot a QDM of 265.

The magnetic variation is 12º W.

The QDR is...

Approaching Rotterdam it appears that you have lost your position.

You ask for a bearing to Rotterdam Tower.

You receive a QDM of 002.

In order to arrive over Rotterdam you should follow...
In which of the following circumstances will VDF most likely be used to determine the position of an aircraft.

options.text: If an aircraft transmits an urgency (pan-pan) call on any frequency.
At first contact after passing the FIR boundary.
If ATC is contacted in order to fly from an uncontrolled airspace to a controlled airspace.
When the pilot transmits a distress call (Mayday) on 121.5 MHz.

questions.query: The transmission of a Locator NDB is...

options.text: a N0N/A3 signal with a voice ident once per minute.
a N0N/A2 signal with a reduced transmission power.
a N0N/A1 signal with a one-letter Morse ident.
a N0N signal because the signal is non-directional.
options.comment:
A N0N signal is an unmodulated carrier wave.

N0N does not mean non-directional.

questions.query: Which antenna(s) are used when the mode switch on the ADF control panel is set to the ANT mode to improve the audio reception?

options.text: Both the sense and the loop antenna.
Nor the sense antenna, nor the loop antenna.

options.comment:
Correct.

Now the ADF-receiver receives a circular polar diagram.

questions.query: Which statement is true for an airway NDB?

options.text: The range of airway NDB's is limited to the radio horizon.
The range of an airway NDB is more than the range of a Terminal VOR.
The accuracy of the line of position (LOP) received from an airway NDB is less during sunrise and sunset.

questions.query: When comparing with airway NDBs, locator NDB's are limited to terminal navigation only because of their...

options.comment: Locator NDB's transmit at reduced power which means their range is usually limited to 10-20 NM.

questions.query: When an ADF receiver uses a loop antenna only to take a bearing of an NDB, and the measurement is based on a minimum reception ('null'), then the bearing is...

options.text: ambiguous and along the plane of the antenna.
unambiguous and perpendicular to the plane of the antenna.
ambiguous and perpendicular to the plane of the antenna.

questions.query:
Which of the following statements regarding NDB's is correct?

  1. Locators always transmits non-directional;
  2. Radio Broadcast Stations can always be used for NBD navigation;
  3. Oceanic NDB's can never be found at land.
An important difference between an Airway NDB and a Locator NDB is...

options.text: radiation pattern: airway NDB's transmits non-directional; locator NDB's transmits directional.
siting: airway NDB's outside airports; locator NDB's at airports.
frequency band: airway NDB's between 190-1750 kHz; locator NDB's between 108-118 MHz.
transmission power: airway NDB's transmit more power; locator NDB's transmit less power.

questions.query: Bearings from aviation NDBs are preferred over bearings from public or commercial radio broadcast stations because the...

options.text: radio broadcast stations use A3 modulated signals which are much more sensitive to disturbances than NDB signals.
position of the antenna of the broadcast station is usually unknown.

questions.query:
Given:

  • True Heading (TH) of the aircraft is 030°;
  • Relative Bearing with the ADF is 160°L;
  • Magnetic variation = 10°W;
  • Deviation = +2°.

The compass bearing on the RMI is...

Given:

  • aircraft at position 52°45'N,006°00'E;
  • ADF is tuned to NDB 'STK' (53°00'N, 006°49'E);
  • TB is 063°;
  • magnetic variation in the area is 1°W;
  • deviation of the compass is +2°;
  • 95% accuracy of the bearing is 2°.

The reading of the RMI will be in 95% of all cases between (rounded off to 0.5°)...

Given:

  • an aircraft tracks radial 315° inbound to a VOR station;
  • the drift is 5°L;
  • the relative bearing of an NDB is 60°R.

The indication on the RMI will be (dev = 0)...
The selected VOR radial is shown on the...
Which statement about CVOR and DVOR is correct?

options.text: A CVOR has a carrier wave that is AM; a DVOR has a carrier wave that is FM.
CVORS are used in terminal areas; DVOR are used at airways.
CVORs transmit in the VHF band; DVORs transmit in the UHF band.
The variable signals of CVOR and DVOR rotate in opposite directions.
options.comment:
Correct.

This is necessary to solve for the difference in REF and VAR.

VAR @ CVOR is 30 Hz AM; REF @ CVOR is 30 Hz FM

VAR @ DVOR is 30 Hz FM; REF @ DVOR is 30 Hz AM.

In the receiver the radial is -traditionally- determined by comparing 30 HZ FM (REF) - 30 Hz AM (VAR).

questions.query: A correct description of a VOT is...

options.text: A beacon that gives a certain radial that is indicated on a VOR checkpoint.
A beacon that is positioned near a terminal and that operates at reduced power.
A monitor station that monitors the VOR transmissions.
A special beacon that gives the aircraft installation the impression that the aircraft is on radial 360.

questions.query: Which statement is true for a VOR?

options.text: VOR's have monitoring stations at the boundary of their designated operational coverage.
The accuracy of a TVOR is better than that of an airway VOR.
The transmission power of a VOT and an TVOR is the same.

questions.query: In aircraft, a bearing of a VOR station can be taken by the...

Given:

  • At VOR TCK (65°13.7'N, 155°21.1'W) the magnetic variation is 24°E;
  • The DR of the aircraft is (64°10.0'N, 152°25.0'W);
  • The magnetic variation 22°E;
  • The deviation is -1°;
  • The heading on the HSI is 255°;
  • The CRS is 290° and the CDI is on the left inner dot;
  • At the moment that the TO/FR indicator changes, the course deviation bar is completely to the right.

On which radial is the aircraft at that moment?

Which of the following statements is true for a conventional airway VOR?

  1. The fixed omni-directional antenna transmits a VHF-carrier wave with the following modulations: a 30 Hz AM reference signa, and a 1020 Hz AM Ident.
  2. The rotating directional antenna transmits a VHF-carrier wave with a 30 Hz FM variable signal.
The VOR radial is determined by measuring the difference in...

options.text: amplitude between the FM and the AM signal.
time between the reception of the two 30 Hz signals.
phase between the reference signal and the variable signal.

questions.query: Which statement regarding VOR is correct?

options.text: The wave length of a CVOR is larger than that of a DVOR.
A DVOR is less sensitive to ionospheric reflections than a TVOR.
The reference for a CVOR is compass North and for a TVOR true North.
A TVOR is used for terminal navigation and a VOT is used for test purposes.

questions.query: The 'site errors' around a VOR are...

options.text: negligible at a TVOR due to the smaller range.
not present at a CVOR due to the 'counterpoise'.
are very small due to the application of vertical polarised antennas.
smaller for a DVOR than for a CVOR due to the antenna system.

questions.query: About the airborne DME installation, it can be said that...

options.text: the DME receiver will go directly to the Search mode when it is switched on.
the interrogator can track a maximum of 90 grounds stations (transponders).
in case of a "loss of lock-on", the Memory mode will be active for about 1 minute.
in the Tracking mode, the pulse repetition frequency is much lower than in the Search mode.
options.comment:
Correct.

About 25 ppps in the tracking mode vs 150 ppps in the search mode.

questions.query: The capacity of a DME ground station is determined by the amount of...

options.text: aircraft that fly within the range of the DME ground station.
interrogators in the search-mode in relation to the amount of interrogators in the tracking-mode.

options.comment:
This has nothing to do with the capacity.

Each DME has - in principle - a CDC of 2700 ppps which results in 90 aircraft based on an average PRF of 30 ppps.

questions.query: Which statement about rho-theta navigation is correct?

options.text: A VORTAC gives direction information only to civil users.
The capacity of the VOR is unlimited, the capacity of the DME is limited to about 100 aircraft.

questions.query: When the plan range between a DME interrogator at FL350, and a transponder at SL is 200 NM, the calculated slant range is...

options.text: not possible as this distance exceeds the designated operational coverage (DOC) range of the DME.

questions.query: The slant range correction for an aircraft flying at FL300 with a DME reading of 100 NM is...

options.comment:
Correct.

FL300 is 30000 ft.

30000 ft is almost 5 NM.

sqrt (1002 - 52) = 99.9 NM.

questions.query: Which statement about DME is true?

options.text: In the standby mode the PRF is reduced to 30 pps to avoid beacon saturation.
The Station Dead (or recovery) time accounts for the internal delay in the processing of the signal.
The transponder determines the slant range by measuring the spacing between two pulse pairs and transmits this to the aircraft.
The interrogator enters the search mode if squitter pulses are received.

questions.query:
An A320neo at FL360 is at 10 NM plan range from a DME with an elevation of 1000 ft.

QNH is 1013 hPa.

 

The DME reading in the aircraft will most likely be...

options.comment:
Only large, modern aircraft fly at 36000 ft.

These aircraft have their DME indication adapted to the altitude showing plan range instead of slant range.

questions.query: The echo protection function of the DME is the...

options.text: avoidance of echo's from secondary radars in the vicinity of the aircraft.
removal of reply pulses intended for other aircraft.
automatic change-over to the Standby mode, in case of no reception of DME signals.
avoidance of replying to pulse pairs reflected from obstacles in the vicinity.

questions.query:
An aircraft flies outbound from a VOR/DME station and crosses the border of the designated operational coverage area.

As soon as the DME-signal is no longer received, the DME interrogator will...

options.text: in case of a 'static memory' show the last determined slant range for about 10 seconds, before switching back to the 'auto standby' mode.
interrogate in the 'tracking mode' with a maximum of 30 pp/second until another station is tuned.
immediately switch to the 'search mode' and start to interrogate with maximum 150 pp/second.
options.comment: When the signal is lost, the interrogator enters the memory mode for max 10-15 seonds; after that auto standby, which means waiting for new pulses to be received.

questions.query: The constant duty cycle of a DME...

options.text: lets the airborne based interrogator transmit squitter pulses when there is no contact with a ground station.
makes sure DME channels are paired to VOR frequencies.
is a system in which the gain of the ground based receiver gain is varied in such a way that the 90-100 strongest signals are answered.

questions.query: An ILS sensitive area is where...

options.text: ground traffic is not allowed when a CAT 1 ILS is in operation.
ground traffic must be controlled during ILS approaches.
traffic is not allowed when ILS calibration flights are in progress.
air traffic is not allowed when a CAT 3 ILS is in operation.

questions.query: A false glideslope of an ILS is the result of...

options.text: beam bends caused by large metal surfaces in the vicinity of the ILS.
atmospheric disturbances such as heavy precipitation and thunderstorms.

questions.query: The ILS critical area is...

options.text: an area around the runway where no vehicles are allowed to drive, in order to keep a safe distance to landing aircraft.
an area around the LLZ as well as the GP antenna, in which the presence of aircraft or other craft causes disturbances of the ILS signal.
situated in front of the Localizer and Glide path antenna; in this area no large craft are allowed during Cat-II or Cat-III approaches.
for an approaching B747 aircraft much larger than for a Diamond Twinstar.

questions.query: The blue outer marker signal of the ILS is...
Which statement is correct regarding ILS-indications?

options.text: The calibration of the course deviation indicator (CDI) depends on the position of the course pointer (CP).
When passing the outer marker (OM), the white light will come on at a rate of 400 Hz.
At an ILS/DME the station delay is adapted in order to show the remaining distance to the end of the runway.
Just before a normal glide-path (GP) intercept, the GP-pointer will have an upward deflection.
options.comment:
Correct.

The GP is intercepted from below to prevent interception of false glide slopes.

questions.query: The minimum range of the ILS localiser transmitter is...

options.text: 25 NM in a sector 17° to both sides of the centreline.
40 NM to an elevation of 1.75 times the glide path angle.
25 NM in a sector of 10° and 17 NM in a sector of 35° on both sides of the centreline.

questions.query: When flying an ILS approach, the following modulation signals will be received...

options.text: 400 Hz and 1350 Hz navigation components plus 90 Hz and 150 Hz identification signals.
75 Hz and 150 Hz navigation signals plus 1020 Hz and 1350 Hz ident signals.
400 Hz, 1300 Hz and 3000 Hz navigation signals plus a 75 Hz ident signal.
90 Hz and 150 Hz navigation components plus a 1020 Hz identification signal.

questions.query: The ILS receiver has an AM detector behind its VHF filter in order to demodulate the...

options.text: identification and navigation signals of the localiser transmission.
transmitted DDM of the marker beacon beacon.
90 Hz and the 150 Hz signal on the glide path carrier.
options.comment:
The difference in depth of modulation (DDM) is not transmitted.

DDM is only used to compare the modulation depths of the two modulation components on the localiser and glidepath carrier.

This is not applicable to the MB's.

questions.query: ILS radio signals are characterised by...

options.text: horizontal polarisation of the localizer signal and vertical polarisation of the glide-slope signal.
a paired Morse identification on the carrier of the localiser and of the glide-slope beacon.
a localiser range of 25 NM and a glide-slope range of 10 NM.

questions.query: Whn flying a 3° glide path with a groundspeed of 100 kt, the rate-of-descent is...
The wave length of the Marker Beacon transmission is...
Which statement for airborne ILS instrumentation is true?

options.text: A filter behind the UHF-receiver demodulates the 90 and 150 Hz signals of the localizer beacon.
Marker beacons are received with the UHF-receivers
The DME-part of an ILS must be manually tuned.
When there are no modulation components on the carries, the DDM is zero and there wil be a flag warning.
options.comment:
When the two modulation components of either LOC or GP are present, and the DDM is zero, the associated deviation bar is centred.

When there are no modulation components, the DDM is also zero and only then there will be a flag warning.

questions.query:
Given an ILS-DME approach.

Three-dimensional guidance to the runway-threshold can be expected from a distance of...
The MLS EL antenna is located...
When comparing with a standard ILS-DME, a standard MLS has...

options.text: more channels and is less sensitive to multipath.

questions.query: The execution of segmented approaches with MLS is only possible if the ground installation is equipped with a...
The working principle of MLS is measuring a time difference between...

options.text: the reception of a TO-scan and a FR-scan.
the transmission of a TO-scan and the reception of a FR-scan.
options.comment: Time difference between the reception of a TO-scan and a FR-scan from a scanning beam.

options.text: the interrogation pulses from the DME and the reply pulses from the AZ and EL antenna.
two pulses: one transmitted from the elevation antenna, the other from the azimuth antenna.

questions.query: The MLS ident is supplied...

options.text: as a pre-amble to the AZ datablock.
as a pre-amble to the EL datablock.

questions.query: Contrary to ILS, MLS does NOT need...

options.text: special receivers in the aircraft, because use is made of the existing DME receiver.
DME receivers, because distance information is obtained via the scanning beams.
dedicated ground antennas for all of its components, because all information is tranmitted via a single rotating beam.
separate antennas to receive the various components, because all information is transmitted on one frequency.

questions.query: MLS has the possibility to offer segmented approaches, which means that...

options.text: MLS offers multiple approaches to different runways.
MLS offers multiple, curved approaches to a single runway.

questions.query:
The distance resolution of radar increases when the…

 

Note:
Distance resolution is ‘afstand onderscheidend vermogen'.
Regarding primary and secondary radar...

options.text: the ground is the primary part (master); the aircraft is the secondary part (slave).
primary radar uses rotating antennas, secondary radar uses stationary antennas.
primary radar is normally active; secondary radar is normally standby and becomes active after the primary radar has failed.
primary radar makes use of passive targets; secondary radar makes use of active targets.

questions.query:
A pulse radar has the following data:

  • frequency 10 GHz;
  • pulse length 1 micro-second;
  • pulse interval 1235 micro-second;
  • antenna diameter 0.7 m.

For this radar it can be stated that the...

options.comment: Correct.

questions.query: The pulse repetition frequency (PRF) of a radar determines the...
A parabolic antenna with a diameter of 18 inch and a frequency of 10 MHz, has a beam width of...

Given:

A radar with a PRF of 666 Hz and a pulse duration of 2 µsec.

 

The maximum theoretical range is...
The maximum theoretical range of a radar depends on...
Primary ground radar must detect aircraft that are NOT equipped with a...
A ground radar...

options.text: has a smaller range than an airborne radar because of ground reflections.

options.comment:
Correct.

The antenna is always on the ground.

questions.query: During a so-called Ground Controlled Approach (GCA), the Precision Approach Radar (PAR)...

options.text: informs tower and approach controllers about the actual weather situation.
allows for circumferential navigation inside the TMA by means of radar vectors.
supplies ground controllers with traffic information on airports.
gives horizontal and vertical guidance into a runway.

questions.query: Short-range, aerodrome radars for traffic on airports will have wavelengths of approximately a few...
Modern ATC systems use the following display unit:

options.text: electron gun in a vacuum glass tube with a rotating timebase and a green phosphoric screen.

questions.query: A primary ground radar...

options.text: interrogates transponders for their squawk code only.

questions.query: A long-range, ground radar has a relative...
The airborne weather radar can NOT detect...
The frequency of weather radar is...

options.comment: This is the MLS carrier wave frequency.

questions.query: An airborne weather radar (AWR) uses interrogation...

options.text: pulses transmitted at a random frequency to detect possible turbulent clouds.
pulse pairs in a random order to allow lock-on on its own replies.
pulse with a length of 3.2 cm for best reflective properties.
pulses of a constant frequency, amplitude, width and rate.

questions.query: A modern weather radar detects windshear by...
An airborne weather radar shows light rain in a [...] colour.
Sensitivity Timing Control (STC) in airborne weather radars is used to...

options.text: automatically adapt the range until the nearest rainshower is shown.
compensate for the weakening of the pulses when passing rainshowers.
account for weaker echoes from targets at larger distances.

questions.query: When the gain of a weather radar is reduced...

options.text: the image in the mapping (and weather) mode may improve.

questions.query: Airborne weather radar operates in which frequency band?
The radio waves of an Airborne Weather Radar (AWR) have a wavelength of about 3 cm, because...

options.text: this reduces the size of the antenna, which can now be placed in the nose of the aircraft.
the radar transceiver now consumes the least power.
this avoids the indication of ground clutter on the screen.
this is the best compromise between absorption and reflection of precipitation.

questions.query: Concerning a weather radar display, what is meant with a ‘shadow area’?

options.text: A black area for the first couple of miles until reaching the minimum detectable range.
A black area in front of the nose until the radar beam reaches the ground.
A black area beyond the maximum calibrated range.
A black area behind a very heavy rainshower.

questions.query: SSR makes use of...

options.text: airborne antennas to interrogate the transponders of other aircraft.
metallic parts in the aircraft construction as a back-up for the PSR.
a ground based transmit/receive antenna and an airborne receive/transmit antenna.

questions.query: A TAR is a radar installation for air traffic control (ATC)...
When comparing with primary radar, secondary radar has the following advantages:

options.text: cheaper, no need for transponder, less fruiting & garbling.
better radar resolution rectangle, 7777 codes instead of 4096, more sensitive antenna.
fixed (non-moving) flat plate antenna, mono (single) pulses instead of pulse pairs, larger wave length.
no ambiguity, larger range, no ground reflections, no rain targets.

questions.query: A Mode-A interrogation requests...
A Mode-S interrogation requests the...

options.text: Special Position Identifier (SPI) or just ‘Ident’ pulse to be transmitted.
surveillance of other aircraft by primary radar and secondary radar.
transmission of information from secondary radars only.

questions.query:
A transponder has the following settings:

  • OFF
  • SBY
  • ON
  • ALT

Which setting represents Mode-S?
The difference between the altitude reporting mode of a Mode-C transponder and a Mode-S transponder is...

options.text: altitude sensor: stacked capsule vs piezo crystal.

questions.query: Which statement is correct regarding primary radar and secondary radar?

options.text: Primary radar uses Mode-A and Mode-C interrogations; secondary radar uses Mode-S interrogations.
Primary radar interrogates the aircraft; secondary radar replies via the transponder.
Primary radar interrogates at 1030 MHz; secondary radar interrogates at 1090 MHz.
Primary radar detects distance and bearing; secondary radar supplies additional information.

questions.query: A secondary radar requires less transmission power than a primary radar because...

options.text: the pulse repetition frequency, the pulse width and the pulse amplitude are lower.
the interrogation signal only has to travel outbound.

questions.query: The altitude of an aircraft that is supplied by the transponder, is relative to...
GPS uses two transmission frequencies because...

options.text: redundancy: in case of failure of one frequency, you can use the other one.
with two frequencies, the tropospheric delay can be determined.
from the difference in arrival time of the signal, the receiver clock error is calculated.
it enables P-code receivers to determine the ionospheric delay.

questions.query: Which of the following statements on GNSS is true?

options.text: When flying from the West to the East, the GNSS has to switch over from GPS, via Galileo and GLONASS to BEIDOU.
NAVSTAR is the Russian version of the US GPS.
Global coverage is achieved by employing a SBAS.

questions.query: Regarding GPS and GLONASS, it can be stated that both systems...

options.text: can make use of each others satellites.
use two frequencies for their civil code.

questions.query: The pseudo-range to a GPS satellite can be solved by adding a...
The GPS ‘pseudo range’ is so-called for, because the...
The American GPS-NAVSTAR lacks (is missing)...

options.text: sensitivity, availability and monitoring.
accuracy, measuring range and alerting.
tolerance, functionality and integrity.
accuracy, availability and integrity.

questions.query:
The reception of four SV's will - most probably - NOT result in a position fix when all four SV's...

  1. are below the five degrees elevation mask angle;
  2. are within five degrees relative bearing from each other;
  3. have the same polarisation;
  4. are in one plane.
The working principle of GPS is...

options.text: to measure the travel time of a coded signal transmitted from the satellite.
to obtain the frequency shift of the 1575 MHz carrier wave by the Doppler effect.
to interrogate the SV and wait for a reply. The runtime is a measure for the distance.
to determine the position of four SV's by decoding the navigation message.
options.comment: Leuk, en wat heb je daar aan?

questions.query: Where GPS uses WGS-84, does GLONASS use...
Which statement regarding GPS is correct ?

options.text: The PPS allows for the reception of two frequencies to estimate the tropospheric delay.
The duration of a complete cycle of the P-code is 1 microsecond.
The C/A-code is encrypted in a Y-code.
In the SPS (Standard Position Service), use is made of only one frequency.
options.comment:
Correct.

The SPS transmits on the L1 frequency only (1575 MHz).

questions.query: The GPS receiver identifies a certain GPS-satellite by...

options.comment:
Correct.

The C/A code is the unique one millisec code.

questions.query: The navigation message of a GPS-satellite contains information about the...
For the civil application of GPS that uses the CA code only, the following information can be retrieved...

options.text:
position: accurate 3D position,

velocity: groundspeed and true airspeed,

path: track and heading,

time: UTC and local time.

questions.query: The Russian GNSS system is named...
In GPS navigation, the position dilution of precision (PDOP) represents the influence of the geometry of the satellite constellation on the...
The navigation message of a GPS satellite...

options.text: only gives data regarding that one satellite.
takes 12.5 minutes to download the first time.

questions.query: Differential GPS (DGPS) is...

options.text: calculating and transmitting differential corrections to receivers in the vicinity.
monitoring and comparing differences between two receivers
measuring and indicating an accurate GPS position using the L1 and L2 frequency.
comparing and adjusting the GPS position with help of a second navigation system like GLONASS.

questions.query:
GPS augmentation must improve...

  1. accuracy;
  2. integrity;
  3. availability.

The most complete answer is...
In a GBAS the VHF Data Block (VDB) supplies the aircraft with approach data plus...

options.text: operational information about possible beam bends, scalloping and noise.
an update about the current weather prevailing at the airport including possible windshear.
meteorological information such as visibility, wind, pressure and temperature.
corrections and integrity information for GNSS satellites in view.

questions.query: The principle of GBAS is...

options.text: to measure on the ground the signal errors in the user and relay the measured errors to the GNSS satellites for correction.
to measure in the aircraft the signal errors in the signals transmitted by GNSS satellites and relay the measured errors to the ground for correction.
to measure in the aircraft the signal errors in the signals transmitted from the user and relay the measured errors to the GNSS for correction.
to measure on the ground the signal errors in the signals transmitted by GNSS satellites and relay the measured errors to the user for correction.

questions.query: RAIM (Receiver Autonomous Integrity Monitoring...

options.text: delivers integrity data to the satellite via the up-link stations after the determination of the correct ephemerides by the master control station.
monitors the satellites via the monitor-stations spread over the earth.
determines differential corrections that can be sent to the users (receivers).
discovers unreliable satellites with a program in the receiver.

questions.query: The American WAAS (Wide Area Augmentation System) can be described as...

options.text: the GPS control segment consisting of monitor stations, a master control station and several uplink stations.
a system that provides differential corrections and navigation signals, transmitted by geostatioanry communication satellites.
a differential station in the vicinity of the aerodrome that transmits correction signals for the pseudo ranges.
a pseudo satellite (pseudolite) just in front of the runway to enable CAT 3 operations with GPS.

questions.query:
In GBAS, use can be made of ground-based pseudo satellites (pseudolites) to improve the vertical dilution of precision (VDOP).

These pseudolites...

options.text: transmit their signal via a space-based satellite.
suffer from the 5 degrees elevation mask angle.
have no 'ionospheric propagation delay' in the measured range.

questions.query: What is a 'Pseudolite'?

options.text: A GPS satellite that transmits corrupt data not suitable for positioning.
A GPS satellite that transmits a pseudo random noise code which allows for the determination of the pseudo range because the clock error is not known.
A communication satellite that transmits, amongst others, 'integrity messages' for GPS.
A ground based transmitter that transmits a specific C/A code including navigation information on the L1 frequency.

questions.query: One of the properties of a LAAS (Local Area Augmentation System) such as GBAS, is that in the appropriate area for approach and landing...

options.text: corrections for ionospheric delay and tropospheric delay are transmitted
GPS may use GLONASS satellites to enhance the accuracy of the position fix.
the GPS altitude is augmented by a barometric altimeter.
integrity monitoring as well as differential corrections are performed.

questions.query: The geostationary Inmarsat satellites, will for endorsement of GPS...

options.text: only generate transmissions for the US WAAS; the EU EGNOS uses other SV’s.
perform the function of a pseudolite in polar areas.

options.comment:
Correct.

Integrity data for WAAS and for EGNOS.

questions.query:
Which of the following statements about GPS is correct?

  1. Multipath-effects are avoided by using a double antenna set.
  2. Multipath-effects cannot be avoided by differential GPS.
Receiver autonomous integrity monitoring (RAIM) is applied in GPS...

options.text: near aerodromes in ground stations to improve the geometry.
to reduce the PDOP in order to improve the position accuracy.
and in Inmarsat-satellites to enable them to function as geostationary GPS-navigation transponders
receivers in order to warn the user when a satellite does not transmit proper signals.

questions.query: Differential GPS is an application that...

options.text: compares the reception of a double GPS installation in the aircraft to measure aircraft attitude.
determines the errors in the pseudo ranges within a limited area.
derives the changes in the runtime measurement to calculate the three dimensional velocity vector.
determines the position by measuring the differences in the pseudo ranges of the different satellites.
options.comment:
DGPS compares the GPS position with a known position and transmits correction signals to user.

In addition, DGPS also takes care of integrity monitoring.

questions.query:
To support GPS, the geostationary communicstion satellites of Inmarsat will transmit...

  1. ranging signals;
  2. differential corrections;
  3. integrity messages.
GBAS signals are sent to the...
GBAS uses for its differential correction signals a datalink that operates between...
PBN continuity is about...

BB193

What factors define the RNP system performance requirements?

options.text: Contrary to RNAV, RNP has no performance requirements.

questions.query: Within the PBN concept, the RNP (required navigation performance) means...

options.text: the diameter of a circle expressed in NM in which the aircraft is expected to be in 95% of the flight time.
the radius of a circle expressed in NM in which the aircraft is expected to be in 95 % of the flight time.
the surface area of a circle expressed in NM2 in which the aircraft is expected to be in 95 % of the flight time.
the radius of a sphere expressed in NM in which the aircraft is expected to be in 95 % of the flight time.

questions.query: Regarding the linear performance requirements of PBN, what is considered a 'time constraint'?

options.text: The flight time necessary to reach the planned route.
The flight time to the active waypoint.
The time limit to reach a certain waypoint.

questions.query: Which statement concerning RNP is true?

options.text: RNP + on-board performance monitoring and alerting = RNAV.
RNAV + on-board performance monitoring and alerting = RNP.
RNP + on-board performance monitoring and alerting = PBN

options.comment:
It takes more to make a PBN system.

Think of requirements such as availability, integrity, functionality and continuity.

questions.query: The RNP (required navigation performance) is the...
Amongst others, which of the following RNP specifications are in use?
Which of the following statements on RNAV and RNP is correct?

options.text:
RNAV is for en-route airspace;

RNP is for terminal airspace.

RNAV is for oceanic/remote airspace;

RNP is for continental airspace.

RNAV is for en-route and terminal airspace;

RNP is for approaches.

RNAV is for en-route and terminal airspace;

RNP is for oceanic/remote-, departure/arrival- and approach airspace.

questions.query: Which of the following statements on navigation performance in relation to minimum route spacing is true?

options.text: A lower RNP increases the minimum route spacing.
A higher RNP increases the minimum route spacing.

questions.query: The path terminator 'FA' is...

options.text: a path from a fix to an altitude

questions.query: In PBN, an FRT leg requires...
In performance based navigation, an off-set flight path allows the flight crew to specify a(n)...
Which PBN waypoint always requires turn anticipation?
In PBN, the flight technical error (FTE) is due to...

options.text: inaccuracies of the technical systems used for in-flight navigation.
options.comment:
That would result in the NSE.

FTE is due to poor track-keeping accuracy of the (auto) pilot.

options.text: an unstable aircraft caused by various reasons (fuel asymmetry, wrong cg, out-of-trim, wrong power setting or coffin corner).
failures of technical systems involved in the control of the aircraft.

questions.query: The navigation database used in PBN operations must be valid for the current four-week [...] cycle.
In case of loss of PBN capability...

options.text: the aircraft should land at the nearest suitable airport under guidance of an other aircraft.
the flight may be continued normally, but after the flight a safety report must be filed.
abnormal and contingency procedure are to be used.

questions.query:
How can the flight crew monitor PBN performance?

  1. regularly check ANP versus RNP;
  2. keep FTE as small as possible;
  3. input waypoint coordinates accurately.
In PBN, the navigation system error (NSE) is shown as...

TB193

The Total System Error (TSE) contains...

options.text: Path Definition Error, Flight Technical Error, Computer System Error.
Path Definition Error, Dead Reckoning Error, Navigation System Error.
Dead Reckoning Error, Navigation Error, Reading error.
Path Definition Error, Flight Technical Error, Navigation System Error.

questions.query: During an RNP approach, the barometric altimeter can only be used when the...

options.text: ambient pressure is within a promulgated range.
air density is within a promulgated range.
outside air temperature is within a promulgated range.

questions.query: During a LPV approach, SBAS may be used for...

options.text: transmission of differential corrections to the baro altimeter.

questions.query:
CS193

RNAV 10 requires that aircraft operating in oceanic and remote areas are equipped with at least [...] independent and servicable LRNSs comprising an INS, an IRS-FMS or a GNSS.

options.text: [one]
[three]
[four]
[two]

questions.query: When performing a RNP APCH to LNAV/VNAV minima, the vertical guidance comes from...

options.text: the co-pilot reading and recalling the barometric altimeter.
the inertial altitude derived from the inertial navigation system.
a radio altimeter integral with the navigation computer.
a separate barometric altimeter integral with the navigation computer.

questions.query: Which RNP APCH is a 3D operation?

options.comment: No, there are als RNP APCH to LNAV minima, which is 2D.

questions.query: In order to fly an RNP APCH, select the approach template from a valid, and up-to-date...

options.text: external navigation data storage device such as a tablet, which is not part of the certified aircraft configuration.
external navigation data storage device such as a hard-copy booklet holding printed versions of all type of approaches.
internal navigation data storage device such as a FMS, which is part of the certified aircraft configuration.

questions.query: The PBN Point-in-Space (PinS) procedure is designed for...

TH193

The prefix 'A' in A-RNP stands for...
